maturity_levels.0: Not in place — Core IT operations lack central management, monitoring, or standards, resulting in unpredictable system behaviour and high operational risk. Executives should expect frequent outages, inefficiency, and elevated security exposure.
maturity_levels.1: Ad hoc — Some operational practices exist but are inconsistent, undocumented, or dependent on individuals. The organisation faces avoidable outages, reactive support, and increased cost due to rework.
maturity_levels.2: Partially implemented — Basic controls such as patching, backups, or monitoring exist, but coverage is uneven. This limits reliability and forces teams to spend time firefighting rather than improving operations.
maturity_levels.3: Defined but inconsistently applied — Standard processes exist for device management, monitoring, and operational checks, but adoption varies between teams. Inconsistent execution increases operational risk and slows recovery during incidents.
maturity_levels.4: Consistently applied — Core IT operations follow defined standards across most systems. Reliability improves, downtime reduces, and operational effort becomes more predictable, lowering overall support costs.
maturity_levels.5: Mature / Optimised — IT operations are automated, predictable, and engineered for resilience. Strong observability and lifecycle management reduce outages, improve service continuity, and free resources for strategic work.

Foundational: Introduce centralised management for core devices (laptops, desktops, key servers).
Ensure critical systems are backed up and begin basic recovery testing.
Implement monitoring for key systems to detect outages and performance issues.
Developing: Expand device management coverage and standardise baseline configurations.
Formalise backup and recovery runbooks with documented responsibilities.
Define alert thresholds and escalation paths for monitoring and incidents.
Established: Automate routine tasks such as patching, health checks, and provisioning.
Standardise configurations across environments to reduce drift and support effort.
Improve system integrations to reduce manual data handling and rework.
Advanced: Adopt predictive monitoring to identify issues before they impact users.
Implement self-healing automation for common operational incidents.
Continuously optimise integrations and workflows to minimise manual intervention.

maturity_levels.0: Not in place — There is no structured service management; incidents and requests are handled informally. Executives face low visibility, poor user experience, and rising operational overhead.
maturity_levels.1: Ad hoc — Some processes exist but are inconsistently followed. Users receive fragmented service, and IT cannot reliably meet expectations or manage demand.
maturity_levels.2: Partially implemented — Core ITSM capabilities exist (ticketing, basic workflows), but service quality varies. Limited automation and inconsistent reviews reduce efficiency.
maturity_levels.3: Defined but inconsistently applied — ITSM processes are documented but not fully embedded. Cross-team workflows still rely on manual steps, preventing consistent performance.
maturity_levels.4: Consistently applied — ITSM is reliable, measured, and repeatable. Expanding into ESM improves cross-department workflows and reduces friction across the organisation.
maturity_levels.5: Mature / Optimised — Service management becomes a business enabler. Automated workflows, strong self-service, and experience (XLA) metrics improve productivity, reduce cost, and streamline enterprise processes.

Foundational: Create a unified service catalog for IT.
Establish basic SLAs for response and resolution.
Developing: Expand the service catalog to include HR or Facilities (ESM).
Implement automated approval workflows for common requests.
Regularly review knowledge base coverage and quality.
Established: Shift focus from SLAs (uptime) to XLAs (experience).
Automate cross-team handoffs to reduce delays.
Implement AI-driven ticket triage and routing.
Advanced: Deploy self-healing bots for common user requests.
Integrate service delivery metrics with business revenue goals.
Achieve >50% automated resolution for standard requests.

maturity_levels.0: Not in place — Key security controls such as MFA, endpoint protection, and logging are missing. The organisation is highly vulnerable to common attacks with significant business risk.
maturity_levels.1: Ad hoc — Some controls exist but are inconsistently used, leaving large gaps in identity protection, patching, and monitoring. Security risk remains high and difficult to quantify.
maturity_levels.2: Partially implemented — Core controls (MFA, antivirus, patching) are deployed but not fully enforced or integrated. Detection capability is limited and response is reactive.
maturity_levels.3: Defined but inconsistently applied — Security standards exist but aren't reliably followed across systems or departments. Visibility gaps slow incident response and increase compliance risk.
maturity_levels.4: Consistently applied — Controls are enforced, monitored, and maintained. Detection and response processes are reliable, lowering the likelihood and impact of security incidents.
maturity_levels.5: Mature / Optimised — Security is intelligence-led with automated detection, response orchestration, and strong governance. Executives gain confidence through measurable risk reduction and continuous assurance.

Foundational: Enforce MFA on all accounts without exception.
Deploy EDR to all endpoints and servers.
Remove standing admin rights from user workstations.
Developing: Implement a SIEM for central log analysis.
Conduct regular vulnerability scans and link to patching.
Establish a formal security awareness program.
Established: Deploy automated response actions (SOAR) for common alerts.
Implement conditional access policies for identity.
Conduct regular table-top incident response exercises.
Advanced: Integrate threat intelligence feeds for proactive blocking.
Adopt a Zero Trust Network Access (ZTNA) model.
Automate red-teaming or breach simulation exercises.

maturity_levels.0: Not in place — There is no formal governance, risk management, or compliance structure. Executives lack visibility into threats, obligations, and business risk.
maturity_levels.1: Ad hoc — Some governance activities occur, but processes are informal and dependent on individuals. Compliance gaps and unmanaged vendor or operational risks may accumulate.
maturity_levels.2: Partially implemented — Framework alignment (E8 / ISO / SMB1001) has begun but is incomplete. Policies exist, but enforcement and reporting are inconsistent.
maturity_levels.3: Defined but inconsistently applied — Governance processes are documented, but execution varies, reducing effectiveness. Risk reviews occur but are not embedded in decision-making.
maturity_levels.4: Consistently applied — Governance, risk, and compliance practices are reliable and repeatable. Executive decisions are informed by structured reporting and predictable risk controls.
maturity_levels.5: Mature / Optimised — Governance is proactive and automated where possible. Real-time assurance, strong vendor oversight, and strategic alignment reduce liability and improve confidence in technology investment.

Foundational: Define a clear IT and Security strategy roadmap.
Identify and document all key vendors and shadow IT.
Developing: Formalise platform governance and admin roles.
Established: Deploy tools for continuous compliance monitoring.
Integrate vendor risk assessments into procurement.
Advanced: Quantify cyber risk in financial terms (e.g., FAIR model).
Align technology roadmaps dynamically with business revenue KPIs.
